intro: Gliricidia sepium, commonly known as the madre de cacao, is a fast-growing leguminous tree native to tropical regions of the Americas. It has compound leaves with 12–20 pairs of elliptical leaflets and produces small, fragrant white flowers that bloom in terminal clusters. The tree is known for its ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen, making it valuable for soil enrichment and agroforestry. Its seeds are encased in long, slender pods and are used in traditional medicine and as a source of livestock feed. The plant is also valued for its hardy nature and adaptability to various soil types.
